text:
- Alright, let's talk
about travel mistakes.
- Mistakes? Me? Never.
- You may be surprised.
(upbeat music)
Hi, everyone, my name is Kristen Sarah,
this is Hopscotch The Globe and I am here
to share with you eight travel mistakes
you need to stop making.
- Seriously? Seriously?
I've read in so many blog posts,
I've watched so many YouTube videos
and so many friends told me
that you're supposed to move slow.
I get it, but this slow? Come on!
My whole trip to Costa Rica is ruined.
So disappointing.
- Setting too many expectations.

Now this can be anything
from expecting a train
to arrive at a certain time and it doesn't

or having an expectation
of a certain experience

or a certain place based on
someone else's experience
or photos you might have seen and you get

to that destination and
nothing as you thought
it was going to be.

Setting yourself up with
too many expectations
is setting yourself up for disappointment

because you're taking an
experience you haven't had yet
and you're playing it out in your head

how you think it's going to be,
and then when you get there,
and it's not what you expected,
this can be disappointing.

So what I say is if you're
going to expect anything,

expect the unexpected
because travel is all about

the unexpected and that is
what makes it so special,

to have these experiences you
could have never determined
were gonna happen to you ahead of time.
That is what makes it so magical.
(upbeat music)

Your trip doesn't start when
you get to your destination.

- Right, it starts when
you board the plane.

- It actually starts a
lot sooner than that.

Thinking the trip starts when
you get to your destination.
It actually starts way before that
in the trip planning stage.
Planning your trip is a big part
of your whole travel experience.

Booking your flight, deciding
where you're gonna go,

where you're gonna stay, how
long you're gonna go for,
what you're gonna do is all part
of the whole overall experience.
Planning your trip is so exciting

because this is when everything
starts to come to life,
so although getting to your destination
is the ultimate goal, trip planning
is when the excitement starts.
(upbeat music)

Thinking your trip ends
when you get back home,
and this is a big one that I think
really throws people off guard

because I get emails daily,
and I have for years,
from people pretty much saying I feel off,

I feel depressed, I feel out
of place, I feel overwhelmed
after coming home from a trip.
Now this could have been a week-long trip,

a month-long, a year-long,
it doesn't really matter,

it's the same feeling that
many of us experience.
I call it Post-Travel Depression

and what happens is you
come back from a trip,

somewhere where you
experienced so many new things,

unique experiences that
you had and it changes you.
It changes you in such a short time

and then you come back to a
place that is so familiar,

where nothing has changed,
a place you call home
and you're a different person,
but nothing else around you is different.
It's a lot to process.
So, allowing yourself to go through that,
to kinda go through your trip,
because you didn't get to do that

when you were traveling,
you're experiencing so much,
but you didn't get to process it.

You come home, that's when
you're gonna process it

and it can take a long
time and talking about it,

going through your
pictures, writing about it,
whatever you need to do to go through it
is important and allow yourself to do it
and don't feel bad about it, don't try to

ask why am I feeling this
way because it is so normal,
so many of us go through it.
(upbeat music)

- So you're saying I need to
learn an entire new language
before I travel to a destination?

- Not an entire language,
but it's good to know
a few key phrases in the language
of the destination that you're going to.
Not learning the language beforehand

and now I'm not trying to
say go and learn an entire
language before you go to the destination

because, realistically,
that would be a freakin'

superpower and if you
can speak every language

on this planet, I wanna
be your best friend.

Most likely, you're not gonna
know the entire language

for each place you visit,
but it's good to know

a few phrases, so like hello,
how are you, I'm hungry,
where's the washroom, these little things
will go a long way.
Not only will it help you get around
and figure things out easier,
but locals will respect you more.

It will also allow you to
have more of a connection
with the place and the people.
You feel more immersed in the culture

when you can speak a
little bit of the language.
(upbeat music)
Traveling to escape your real life.
So many people make this mistake.

They think that if they
travel across the world,

that they're gonna all of
the sudden have no problems,
that all the problems they had back home

or stress-related issues
are just going to melt away
like that and it doesn't happen that way.

You still have to process
them, but traveling

can definitely help you
do it because it opens
you up to a new world, new experiences,

to see people around the world
who are exactly how you are,

who are going through
the exact same things,

even though they live a
completely different life.
It allows you to understand yourself more,
it allows you to go through challenges
and learn how to deal with them better,

so, ultimately, can help
you with those issues
that you're dealing with back home,

but it's not gonna just make
all those problems melt away.
(upbeat music)
- (gasp) ♪ I found you! ♪

It only took six flights,
five cars, two taxis,

one train, three buses,
and a 100 kilometer hike,
♪ But I found you, I found you ♪
- Traveling to find yourself.
This is similar to the last point.
Having that expectation that you can go
on a one-week retreat somewhere and then,
all of the sudden, find yourself
is putting a lot of pressure on yourself

and setting yourself
up for disappointment.

Again, we're going back
to the expectations of
I'm going on a soul-searching journey

is different than I'm going
to find myself in Italy.

Travel does have a way of
helping you to understand

the person you are or
the person you want to be

because it shows you
your likes and dislikes.
It allows you to surround yourself

with people that inspire you,
people that you relate to.

It allows you to face those
fears and try new things

and see how similar we
all are around the world,
even though we live different lifestyles.

So, yes it help you
understand better who you are,
but going on a trip with the expectation
that you're going to find yourself,

again is really setting
yourself up to be disappointed

because it's not a game,
but ultimately travel

is a great way to learn
more about yourself.
(upbeat music)

- OMG I just got back from
Paris, it was just a weekend trip
but you must have been following me,

it's all over my Instagram,
my Facebook, my Twitter,

my YouTube, my blog, my
everything. Of course my Snapchat.

- Traveling to brag about
it, this one's a big one,
in this day in age with social media,
specifically Instagram.

I have found that a lot of
people that I used to follow

would post these pictures
that were very curated,
more like modeling shoots,

of places they've been
to around the world,

and more or less bragging about
it instead of inspiring me.
There's a difference between saying
hey look at me, I'm here,

and inspiring people to go and
travel to these destinations.

That's the difference between
influencer and a model.
Not to say that these photos
aren't beautiful because they are,

but traveling to places just
to take the photo to post
to say I've been here is not travel.

Travel is about getting
out into this world

and experiencing new things,
meeting different people,
learning that we are so similar,

what we see in the media
is far from the truth
of how reality actually is.

It's about stepping out
of your comfort zone.
It's about trying new things,
it's about living different ways of life.
It's about opening up your eyes
and being present in the moment

and if you can share a photo
and get that message across,
I don't think that's bragging about it,
I think that's inspiring.
There's a difference.
(upbeat music)

- So what do you mean by
traveling through the lens only?

- Traveling through the
lens and the lens only.

This is something I've
struggled with over the years.
What I mean by this is always
having your camera ready to go to record,

to take photos of a new
experience during your travels.

It's great, it's great
to have these experiences

you're having documented so
you can look back on them

for years to come or share
them with friends and family,
but if you're not really experiencing it,
if you're just looking through a lens

and that is your memory
of this travel experience,
then what's the point?

You might as well just
watch a video on YouTube.

Put that camera down and
experience the experience
for yourself first and foremost.

Be present because that is
the whole point of travel.
If you're not gonna do this,

if you're not gonna
really soak up the moment,
then what's the point of it?

Now I wanna hear from you guys,
let's open up a little bit.

Share with me, share with
all of us one of the mistakes
that I mentioned that you've made
because I've made these mistakes,
that's how I know they're mistakes,
why you shouldn't make them.
But I'd love for you to pick one, pick two
and share with us an experience
that you had that you learned from,

and also if you have any
other travel mistakes
that you wanna share with us,
leave them in the comment section below.
I cannot wait to read them.
(upbeat music)
